channel.title: BBC News - Latin America & Caribbean

item.title: Pedro Castillo declared president-elect of Peru
item.description: The leftist candidate won the popular vote but had been accused of fraud by rival Keiko Fujimori.

item.title: Haiti: Wife of assassinated President Jovenel Moïse returns after surviving attack
item.description: Wearing a bulletproof vest, Martine Moïse arrives home after receiving treatment in the US.

item.title: Brazil's Bolsonaro leaves hospital after treatment for blocked intestine
item.description: The Brazilian president was treated for continuing complications after a near-fatal 2018 stabbing.

item.title: Covid-19: Second doses run dry in Brazil's scramble to vaccinate
item.description: Many are struggling to source their second dose of the Covid-19 jab in one of the worst-hit countries.

item.title: Latin American Foto Festival: Strength and resistance
item.description: Caribbean and Latin American photography features in the fourth Annual Latin American Foto Festival.

item.title: Jovenel Moïse: Colombia ex-soldiers 'in on plot to kill Haiti president'
item.description: Some of the suspects in the murder of Haiti's leader were duped, but others allegedly knew of the plan.

item.title: Cuba protests: Tax on food and medicine imports lifted
item.description: In response to rare protests, Cuba will temporarily allow travellers to bring in some goods tax-free.

item.title: Colombia bets on privately funded Covid vaccinations
item.description: The private-sector scheme allows companies to vaccinate their Colombian staff, regardless of need.

item.title: Cuba protests: Frustration at government runs deep
item.description: Comments on state media show Cubans had been voicing their anger long before the latest protests.

item.title: Cuba protests: Internet sheds light on anger - until it goes dark
item.description: Social media played a key role in rare protests, and the government moved quickly to restrict it.

item.title: Cuba protests: Three key issues that explain the rare unrest
item.description: Cuba has been plunged into turmoil by unusual protests. We look at the main drivers of unrest.

item.title: Climate change: Technology boosts efforts to curb tree loss in Amazon
item.description: Smartphones and satellite data help indigenous people in the Peruvian Amazon to limit deforestation.

item.title: Haiti president's assassination: What we know so far
item.description: Haitian President Jovenel Moïse was shot dead in his private residence in the capital, Port-au-Prince.

item.title: Debbie Harry on Blondie's 'monumental' Cuba trip and her reunion demands
item.description: The star recalls two historic concerts in Havana, and reveals her demand before reforming Blondie.

item.title: Cuba: Rare protests see thousands on streets
item.description: Protesters say they are angry about the government’s handling of both coronavirus and the economy.

item.title: Colombian anti-government protesters topple Columbus statue
item.description: Anti-government protesters in Colombia have toppled a statue of Christopher Columbus in the coastal city of Barranquilla.

item.title: Sea lion opens gate to crash fisherman's interview about a 'plague of sea lions'
item.description: A sea lion was caught on camera crashing an interview with a fisherman about a "plague of sea lions".

item.title: US migrant camp 'kids feel like they're in prison'
item.description: More than 2,000 migrant children are being detained in an overcrowded camp in Texas ridden with disease.

item.title: Windrush Day 2021: 'I wanted to put my culture out there'
item.description: Choreographer Rosy May produces performance on the evolution of Caribbean dance.
